reviewText: Continuing in the previous year's tracks, this season begins in San Francisco as Seth Adams, Bill Hawks, and Charlie Wooster (Ward Bond, Terry Wilson, Frank McGrath), having sworn off sea travel after their experience as shanghaied sailors, decide to return East by stagecoach—and find that their driver is none other than scout Flint McCullough (Robert Horton)!  From there they make their way to St. Joseph and back across country, encountering en route a nave and eager greenhorn (Mickey Rooney), a female journalist who captures Adams's interest (Claire Trevor, who 20 years earlier had twice played opposite Bond's good friend John Wayne in "Stagecoach" and "Allegheny Uprising"), a Basque shepherd (Ernest Borgnine, with a pre-"Star-Trek" Leonard Nimoy playing one of his sons), a supposed girls'-finishing-school headmistress (Bette Davis in a repeat appearance), a Cavalry officer's daughter (Ann Blyth) with a very low opinion of McCullough, a retired sea captain (Ed Wynn) determined to retain custody of his young grandson, a rancher's widow (Judith Anderson) running her inherited spread like a queen, a transplanted Louisianan (Andy Devine) who's raised five daughters in a hidden valley paradise, an Army brat (Brandon DeWilde) anxious to escape the military career his father plans for him, an Italian nobleman (Gustavo Rojo), a young white woman in Indian dress (Luana Patten) living alone and unspeakingly as a healer with a band of wolves for company, a dying woman (Diane Brewster) whose murder Adams undertakes to solve, a Cavalry officer (John Howard) and the half-Comanche hostile chief (James Best) he helped raise, a hard-as-nails mother (Jean Hagen) with a secret, a lawless young man (Tommy Sands) who puts on a very convincing innocent act, a woman (Elaine Stritch) searching for the son she bore in prison, an English archaeologist (Peter Lorre) hunting a hidden cache of Aztec treasure, a “maiden lady” (Phyllis Thaxter, also making a second appearance) and the dozen orphan boys she's taken in, a slick and deadly con artist (Dan Duryea in his third role in the series), a spoiled and rebellious rich girl (Susan Oliver) who badly needs taming, a former scout (Noah Beery Jr.) whom Hawks must run down after his hunting threatens to bring Indian retaliation on the wagon train, a Russian countess (Taina Elg) en route to Alaska, a crippled boy (Tommy Nolan), a disillusioned former clergyman (Donald Woods), and a medicine showman (David Wayne) complete with vegetarian lion!  There's a two-part episode following the trial of an accused murderer, with Henry Daniell and Henry Hull as opposing counsels; a segment in which an exhausted Flint quits the outfit only to find himself drugged and put to work as a slave laborer on a crew digging an intended railroad tunnel; one based loosely on Dickens's "Great Expectations;" and much more—including one (“Dr. Swift Cloud”) said to be set four years after last season's “Swift Cloud Story,” the latter of which (if you have issues with dating) should probably therefore be considered as a flashback to a previous journey.  As is the pattern for this classic series, some episodes are straight Western adventure; some are romance; many have touches of melodrama; some are fables, like “The Sam Livingston Story,” in which the title character, having struck it rich in Montana, moves to take a 19-years-overdue revenge on the ex-partner who jumped his California claim; and some are seriocomic, like “The Charlene Brenton Story,” in which softhearted Charlie Wooster, under the mistaken notion that an orphaned infant has been marked for death, quietly absconds with her, smuggles her onto the wagon train, manages to keep her fed, dry, and hidden for several days, and ultimately bonds with her.As always, continuity is sometimes a problem: distance shots occasionally show one of the regulars wearing different clothes or riding a different horse than he is in closer ones, geography is sometimes a bit muddled and Indian tribes referred to out of their proper range.  And as is usually true of classic-era TV Westerns, the dating is confused: mention is made of “Porfirio Diaz, the hope of Mexico” (possibly in the act of overthrowing Tejada, which he did in 1876), Custer's Last Stand (also 1876), Ben-Hur (published 1880), and even the Boer War (1899-1902), but the year is also once said to be 1868, another time 1869, and reference is made to ongoing negotiations for the sale of Russian America to the U.S.  (As the old saying has it, “You pays your money and you takes your choice”—or, like me, you take the first-season two-parter “The Major Adams Story” as a benchmark, ignore the dates where you can, and otherwise assume that stories are being told out of their proper order, or that all this is happening in a parallel Universe where history didn't go quite the way it did in ours.)  Stellar guests (country star Johnny Cash appears in a brief role as a passenger, Elisha Cook has a nice turn as a quiet yet willing-to-commit-murder wagon driver whose great redeeming trait is his loyalty to the woman who employs him, and Stacy Keach has a blink-and-you-might-miss-him part in “The Danny Benedict Story”), flashes of humor, and frequent hints of backstory on the four regulars enliven the season.

reviewText: season 3 in the same ridiculous packaging as the previous two seasons...once you slide them out, dont put them back again, and again, each and every disk has scuffs, nics and scratches.however this time luck was with me, only one disk, one espisode had a bad break in the picture, and one other episode had one skip.....huge improvement over the past two seasons although new disk should not be received by the customer with these scuffs and sratches, that is why i deducted one star.....but of course, the content is excellent, a lot of flint, stories equally as good as the other seasons, with the exception of the packaging, no reason not to buy and enjoy wagon train.....gosh, this is such wonderful tv entertainment, i refuse to watch wagon train unless i am using my camping mug for coffee while watching...crazy, huh

reviewText: The TV Show is great, definitely rates 5 stars.  However, this company that produces the DVD box set unfortunately seems to use low quality DVD discs.  Every time I got a replacement, there was a defect with one, two or three or the DVD discs in the Box set.  I have had this problem with other DVD box sets put out by this company.I am hoping that Amazon might read this and bring this to the attention of the comapny that produced this DVD box set.  This company puts out some good western TV shows out in DVD box sets.  It's a crying shame that they are made with low quality DVD discs and you have to go through the time and trouble of returning the defective DVD box sets.
summary: The DVD Box Sets Seem to Have Low Quality Discs with Defects
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a groundbreaking series with each episode approaching movie length and with notable film actors in guest roles.  Ward Bond was of course magnificent, and the episodes carried more of the feelings of cherished western movies than did most TV westerns of the time which tended to be on the claustrophobic side.

reviewText: Wagon Train is my all time favorite television series & this is a quality DVD set from one of the years that Flint McCullough (my favorite character) was in the series. I have to give this set a top rating.Some of the best episodes in this season 3 set are:* Benjamin Burns - Possibly the # 1 best episode of WT.  Contains a very memorable scene that kept everyone in my family perched on the edge of the sofa, leaning forward, & eyes focused on the TV throughout the following commercial, when this first aired 50 years ago.* Jess Macabee - An amusing but tender story, featuring Andy Devine as the father of five daughters. In a memorable scene Flint tells each daughter why she is special.* Felizia Kingdom - Featuring Judith Anderson as the strong-willed owner of a large ranch.* Larry Hanify -  Featuring Tommy Sands. About Flint having too much trust in the character of the son of an old friend.Folks who like eerie stories will like Joshua Gilliam, with Dan Duryea as the guest star.Ruth Marshall (about a woman who lives with wolves) and Alexander Portlass (Peter Lorre searches for Aztec gold) will appeal to people who are O.K. with episodes with improbable fantasy plots.The Stagecoach Story (the season premiere) has a western movie feel & uses different stock footage than usual.Cappy Darrin is a good story about a sea captain and a boy.The content is excellent:  My favorite TV series and many good episodes.  In my opinion only season 2 has a somewhat better collection of episodes.The set has fine picture and sound quality. The episodes are complete.  I haven't had any problems with discs skipping or hanging.  The packaging (cardboard book of discs in a decorative tin) wouldn't be my first choice, but it is O.K.  Unlike season 1, discs come out of the cardboard book without any difficulty.One small complaint:  The physical labels on the discs don't clearly say Disc 1, Disc 2, etc. A small disc ID number (69305, 69315, 69325, .... 69395) can be used to sort the discs in original broadcast order.  This is a little bothersome if you have moved the discs to something like Tyvek sleeves because you don't like the cardboard book.Overall, I am very pleased to have this set and have pre-ordered the season 4 set coming out soon.  I'm hoping that Timeless will soon release a season 5 set -- preferably with the several season 5 color episodes in COLOR.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We love Wagon Train. It is filled with heart felt sentimental stories all the way through. I love the era of the 1800's, and Wagon Train does a good job of letting us see what life was like for the Pioneers and Settlers of yesteryear. Will collect them all!
